article:
During my junior year in high school, Mr. Reynolds, my English teacher, handed each student a list of thoughts or statements written by other students. Then he gave us a creative writing   _  based on one of those thoughts.
At 17, I was beginning to   _  about many things, so I   _  the statement, "I wonder why things are the   _  they are?" That night, I wrote down in the form of a   _   all the questions that   _  me about life. I realized that many of them were   _  to answer, and perhaps others could not be23 _  at all.
When I turned in my paper, I was   _   that I might fail the assignment because I had not    _   the question, "I wonder why things are the way they are?" I had no answers. I had   _   written questions. 
The next day Mr. Reynolds called me to the   _  of the class and asked me to   _    my story for other   _  . He handed me30 _  paper and sat down in the back of the room. The class became   _   as I began to read my story:
Mommie, Daddy...  _  ?
Mommie, why are the roses red?
Mommie, why is the grass green and the sky blue?
At the   _  of my story, my eyes locked with Mr. Reynold's eyes, and I saw tears slowly sliding down his cheek. It was then that I   _   that life is not always   _   on the answers we receive, but also on the questions that we ask.
